How to Answer the Desired Salary Question: Expert Tips for Job Seekers

Understanding the Desired Salary Question

The desired salary question is a common part of job interviews and applications. Employers ask this to see if your salary expectations match their budget. It’s a tricky question because you don’t want to ask for too little or too much.

When an employer asks about your desired salary, they want to know:

• How much you think you’re worth

• If they can afford you

• How to make you a fair offer

Answering this question well is important. If you ask for too little, you might get paid less than you deserve. If you ask for too much, the employer might think you’re too expensive and not hire you.

There are a few key things to keep in mind about the desired salary question:

• It often comes up early in the hiring process

• Your answer can affect if you move forward

• There are ways to answer without giving an exact number

• You should be ready to discuss salary at some point

The goal is to keep your options open while showing you have realistic expectations. With some preparation, you can answer this question in a way that helps you get a fair salary.

Research Salary Ranges Before Interviewing

Before you talk about salary in an interview, it’s very important to do research. You need to know what people usually get paid for the job you want. This helps you ask for a fair amount.

Here are some good ways to research salaries:

• Look at salary websites like Glassdoor, Payscale, or Salary.com

• Check job postings for similar roles to see salary ranges

• Ask people you know in the same field what they make

• Look at salary surveys for your industry

• Check with professional groups in your field

When you research, make sure to look at:

• Salaries for your specific job title

• Pay in your city or area

• How much experience affects pay

• Any special skills that might increase pay

It’s also good to know about the company you’re applying to. Big companies might pay more than small ones. Some industries pay more than others too.

Write down the lowest and highest salaries you find. This gives you a range to work with. Most jobs will pay somewhere in the middle of this range.

Remember, your research is just a starting point. Your actual salary might be different based on your skills and the exact job. But knowing the usual range helps you ask for a fair amount.

Strategies to Delay the Salary Discussion

Sometimes, it’s better to wait before talking about salary. You want to learn more about the job first. Here are some ways to delay the salary talk:

• Say you want to know more about the job before discussing pay

• Ask about the job duties and responsibilities instead

• Talk about how you’re a good fit for the role

• Ask what the salary range is for the position

You could say something like: “I’d like to learn more about the role and what it involves before discussing salary. Could you tell me more about the day-to-day responsibilities?”

Or: “I’m really interested in this position. Before we talk about salary, could you share what you have budgeted for this role?”

If they keep asking, you can say: “I’m open to a fair salary based on the responsibilities of the role. Could you share the range you have in mind?”

The goal is to get more information before you give a number. This helps you avoid asking for too little or too much.

Remember, it’s okay to delay the salary talk, but be ready to discuss it eventually. You don’t want to seem like you’re avoiding the topic completely.

How to Provide a Salary Range

If you need to give a salary range, here’s how to do it:

• Use your research to pick a realistic range

• Make the low end of your range something you’d be happy with

• Set the high end a bit above what you expect

• Keep the range fairly narrow, like a $10,000-$15,000 spread

For example, you might say: “Based on my research and experience, I’m looking for a salary in the range of $60,000 to $70,000.”

When you give a range:

• Be ready to explain why you chose that range

• Show that you’re flexible but have done your homework

• Make sure the low end is still okay for you

You could add: “I believe this range is in line with market rates for this position, but I’m open to discussing it further.”

Remember, giving a range can be better than one exact number. It gives you and the employer room to negotiate.

If the employer’s range is lower than yours, you can say: “I appreciate that information. Can you tell me more about the overall compensation package, including benefits?”

This keeps the conversation going and shows you’re considering the whole offer, not just the salary.

Justifying Your Salary Expectations

When you talk about the salary you want, it’s important to explain why you think you deserve that amount. This is called justifying your salary expectations. Here’s how to do it:

• Talk about your skills and experience

• Mention any special training or certifications you have

• Explain how you can help the company

• Use examples from your past jobs

For example, you could say: “I’m asking for this salary range because I have 5 years of experience in this field and a certification in [specific skill]. In my last job, I helped increase sales by 20%, which shows the value I can bring to your company.”

Other things you can mention:

• Awards or recognition you’ve received

• How your skills match what they’re looking for

• Any unique skills that are hard to find

• Results you’ve achieved in past jobs

It’s also good to show you understand the job market. You could say: “Based on my research of similar positions in this area, this salary range is competitive for someone with my skills and experience.”

Remember to be confident but not boastful. The goal is to show why you’re worth the salary you’re asking for.

If the employer seems unsure, you can ask: “What skills or experience would make a candidate worth the higher end of the salary range?” This shows you’re willing to learn and grow in the role.

Negotiating After Receiving a Job Offer

When you get a job offer, you can still talk about the salary. This is called negotiating. Here’s how to do it:

• Thank them for the offer

• Show you’re excited about the job

• Ask for some time to think about it

• Look at the whole offer, not just the salary

You could say: “Thank you for the offer. I’m very excited about the opportunity to work with your team. Could I have a day or two to review the details?”

When you’re ready to negotiate:

• Be polite and professional

• Explain why you’re asking for more

• Be ready to compromise

For example: “I appreciate the offer of $60,000. Given my experience and the responsibilities of the role, would you consider $65,000? I believe this better reflects the value I can bring to the team.”

Remember to think about the whole package:

• Salary

• Benefits (like health insurance)

• Vacation time

• Work from home options

• Training opportunities

If they can’t raise the salary, you could ask: “Is there flexibility in other areas of the compensation package, such as additional vacation days or professional development opportunities?”

Be prepared for them to say no. If that happens, you need to decide if you’re okay with the original offer.

Always end the conversation positively, even if you don’t get what you want. You might say: “I understand. Thank you for considering my request. I’m still very interested in the position and look forward to joining the team.”

Handling Desired Salary on Online Applications

Many online job applications ask for your desired salary. This can be tricky because you don’t want to price yourself out of the job or ask for too little. Here’s how to handle it:

• If possible, leave it blank

• If you must fill it in, use a range instead of a single number

• Write “negotiable” if the form allows text

• Use 999 or 000 as a placeholder if numbers are required

If you decide to put a range:

• Make sure the low end is a salary you’d accept

• Use your research to make sure the range is realistic

• Keep the range fairly narrow, like $5,000-$10,000 apart

For example, you might put $50,000-$60,000 if that’s appropriate for the job and your experience.

Some applications might ask for your current salary. Be careful with this:

• In some places, it’s illegal for employers to ask this

• If you must answer, be honest but include your total compensation, not just base salary

• You could write “prefer to discuss during interview” if allowed

Remember, the goal is to get to the interview stage. Once you’re talking to a real person, you’ll have more chances to discuss salary in detail.

If there’s a comments section, you could write: “I’m open to discussing salary further during the interview process, as I’d like to learn more about the specific responsibilities of the role.”

This shows you’re flexible and interested in more than just the money.

Common Mistakes to Avoid

When talking about salary, there are some mistakes you should try to avoid. Here are the most common ones:

• Giving a number too soon

• Asking for too little

• Asking for way too much

• Not doing research on typical salaries

• Talking only about money, not the job itself

• Lying about your current or past salary

• Accepting the first offer without negotiating

• Seeming desperate or too eager

Here’s why these are problems:

Giving a number too soon: This can limit your options. It’s better to learn more about the job first.

Asking for too little: You might get paid less than you’re worth. It can be hard to get big raises later.

Asking for way too much: The employer might think you don’t understand the job or the market.

Not doing research: You need to know what’s normal for the job. Otherwise, you might ask for the wrong amount.

Talking only about money: This can make you seem like you only care about the paycheck, not the work.

Lying about salary: If the employer finds out, you could lose the job offer or even get fired later.

Accepting without negotiating: Many employers expect some negotiation. You might miss out on a better offer.

Seeming desperate: This can make the employer think they can offer you less.

To avoid these mistakes:

• Do your research

• Practice how you’ll talk about salary

• Focus on the value you bring to the job

• Be honest but strategic in your answers

• Remember that salary is just one part of a job offer

By avoiding these common mistakes, you’ll be in a better position to get a fair salary that matches your skills and experience.

Sample Responses to the Desired Salary Question

Here are some good ways to answer when someone asks about your desired salary. You can use these as examples and change them to fit your situation:

1. When you want to learn more first:

“I’m excited about this position and would love to learn more about the responsibilities before discussing salary. Could you tell me more about what the job involves?”

2. When you want to know their range:

“I have a range in mind based on my research and experience, but I’d be interested to know what you have budgeted for this position. Could you share the salary range you’re considering?”

3. When you’re ready to give a range:

“Based on my experience and the market rates for this role, I’m looking for a salary in the range of $X to $Y. However, I’m open to discussing this further as I learn more about the position and the overall compensation package.”

4. When you want to focus on value:

“I’m looking for a salary that reflects the value I can bring to your team. In my last role, I [mention a specific achievement]. I’m confident I can bring similar results to your company. What range do you typically offer for someone with my experience and skills?”

5. When you’re flexible:

“I’m flexible on salary and more interested in finding the right fit where I can contribute and grow. Can you tell me more about the overall compensation package, including benefits and opportunities for advancement?”

6. When it’s early in the process:

“At this stage, I’m more focused on learning about the role and how I can contribute to your team. I’m sure if we decide we’re a good fit, we can agree on a fair salary. Could you tell me more about what you’re looking for in an ideal candidate?”

7. When you’re asked on an application:

“Negotiable” or “$X-$Y, open to discussion based on overall compensation package”

Remember, the key is to be polite, show interest in the job, and keep the conversation going. You want to avoid giving a specific number too early, but also show that you have realistic expectations.

Considering Benefits Beyond Base Salary

When thinking about a job offer, it’s important to look at more than just the base salary. There are many other benefits that can add value to your overall compensation. Here are some things to consider:

• Health insurance

• Retirement plans (like 401(k) with company match)

• Paid time off (vacation days, sick days, personal days)

• Flexible work hours

• Work from home options

• Bonuses or profit sharing

• Stock options or equity

• Professional development or education reimbursement

• Gym memberships or wellness programs

• Commuter benefits

• Childcare assistance

• Life or disability insurance

These benefits can be worth a lot of money. For example, good health insurance might save you thousands of dollars a year. A company match on your 401(k) is like getting extra salary for retirement.

When discussing salary, you can ask about the total compensation package. You might say: “Can you tell me more about the full benefits package? I’d like to understand the total value of the compensation.”

If the base salary is lower than you hoped, you can ask about other benefits: “Is there flexibility in other areas of compensation, such as additional vacation time or professional development opportunities?”

Some benefits to pay special attention to:

• Health insurance: Look at the coverage and how much you’ll pay

• Retirement plans: Check if there’s a company match and how much

• Paid time off: More vacation days can be very valuable

• Flexible work: The ability to work from home can save time and money

Remember, a job with a slightly lower salary but great benefits might be worth more overall than a job with a higher salary but few benefits.

When comparing job offers, make a list of all the benefits for each job. Try to put a dollar value on each benefit. This can help you see which offer is really better.

Don’t be afraid to ask questions about benefits during the interview process. Understanding the full package will help you make the best decision about your career and compensation.

The Right Time to Discuss Salary

Knowing when to talk about salary is important. Here are some tips on timing:

• Early in the process: It’s usually best to avoid detailed salary talks

• During initial screening: You might be asked about salary expectations

• Middle of the interview process: You can ask about the salary range

• After you’ve impressed them: This is a good time to discuss salary

• When you get a job offer: Now is the time to negotiate

Early in the process:

If asked about salary early, you could say: “I’d like to learn more about the role before discussing salary. Can you tell me more about the responsibilities?”

During initial screening:

If a recruiter asks about salary, you might say: “I’m looking for a competitive salary based on the role and my experience. What range have you budgeted for this position?”

Middle of the interview process:

After a couple of interviews, you could ask: “Now that I understand more about the role, could you share the salary range you’re considering for this position?”

After you’ve impressed them:

Once they seem interested in you, it’s safer to discuss salary. You might say: “I’m very interested in this opportunity. Can we discuss the compensation package you’re offering?”

When you get a job offer:

This is the best time to negotiate. You could say: “Thank you for the offer. I’m excited about the role. Based on my research and experience, I was hoping for a salary closer to [your desired amount]. Is there room for discussion on this?”

Remember:

• It’s usually better if the employer brings up salary first

• Don’t discuss salary until you’re sure they’re interested in you

• Be prepared to discuss salary at any time, just in case

• If you’re not comfortable with the salary talk, it’s okay to politely delay it

The goal is to have the salary discussion when you have the most information about the job and when the employer is most interested in hiring you. This gives you the best chance of getting a good offer.

Tools and Resources for Salary Research

Doing good salary research is important when you’re looking for a job. Here are some helpful tools and resources you can use:

• Salary websites:

• Glassdoor

• Payscale

• Salary.com

• Indeed Salary

• Government resources:

• Bureau of Labor Statistics

• O*NET OnLine

• Professional associations in your field

• Job search websites (look at job postings)

• Networking with people in your industry

• Company review websites

• Salary calculators

How to use these tools:

1. Salary websites: Enter your job title, location, and experience. These sites will show you average salaries.

2. Government resources: These give detailed information about salaries and job outlooks for many careers.

3. Professional associations: Many have salary surveys for their industry.

4. Job search websites: Look at many job postings for your role to see salary ranges.

5. Networking: Talk to people in your field about typical salaries. Be polite and don’t ask for exact numbers.

6. Company review websites: Some have salary information shared by employees.

7. Salary calculators: These tools use your information to estimate a fair salary for you.

Tips for using these resources:

• Check multiple sources to get a full picture

• Look at salaries for your specific location

• Consider how your experience level affects salary

• Think about company size and industry when looking at numbers

• Remember that total compensation includes more than just salary

When you use these tools, you’ll get a good idea of what salary to expect. This helps you ask for a fair amount and know if an offer is good.

Remember, these tools give averages and ranges. Your specific salary might be different based on your unique skills and the exact job.

Using these resources shows employers that you’ve done your homework and have realistic expectations. This can help in your salary discussions.

How Desired Salary Varies by Industry

Different industries often have different salary ranges. This is important to know when you’re job hunting or discussing salary. Here’s how salaries can vary:

• Technology: Often has higher salaries, especially for specialized skills

• Healthcare: Can have good salaries, especially for doctors and specialists

• Finance: Usually offers higher salaries, especially in big cities

• Education: Often has lower salaries but might have good benefits

• Non-profit: Typically lower salaries but can be rewarding in other ways

• Government: May have lower salaries but often has good job security and benefits

• Retail: Often has lower base salaries but might offer commissions

• Manufacturing: Salaries can vary widely based on skill level and location

Why this matters:

• Your desired salary should match industry norms

• Switching industries might mean a change in salary expectations

• Some industries pay more for certain skills than others

Things to consider:

1. Cost of living: Some industries are concentrated in expensive cities, which affects salaries.

2. Supply and demand: Industries with skill shortages often pay more.

3. Profit margins: Industries with high profits often pay employees more.

4. Career growth: Some industries offer faster advancement and salary growth.

5. Work-life balance: Lower-paying industries might offer better hours or less stress.

When discussing salary, you could say: “I understand that salaries in [your industry] typically range from [X] to [Y] for this role. Given my experience and skills, I believe a salary in the [specific range] would be appropriate. Does this align with what you had in mind for this position?”

Remember to research salaries specific to your industry and role. This helps you have realistic expectations and makes salary discussions easier.

If you’re changing industries, you might say: “I realize that salaries in this industry might differ from my previous experience. Can you help me understand the typical range for this role in your company?”

Understanding industry differences helps you navigate salary discussions more effectively and set realistic expectations for your career path.

Adjusting Expectations Based on Experience Level

Your experience level plays a big role in what salary you can expect. Here’s how experience typically affects salary:

• Entry-level: Usually the lowest salaries, as you’re just starting out

• 1-3 years: Slightly higher, as you’ve gained some skills

• 3-5 years: Often a significant jump, as you’re now experienced

• 5-10 years: Higher salaries, especially if you’ve taken on more responsibility

• 10+ years: Usually the highest salaries, reflecting your expertise

How to adjust your expectations:

1. Entry-level:

– Research starting salaries in your field

– Focus on learning opportunities and growth potential

– Be open to negotiating other benefits if salary is fixed

2. Mid-level (3-5 years):

– Look at average salaries for your role and experience

– Highlight specific achievements from your work history

– Consider asking for performance-based bonuses

3. Experienced (5+ years):

– Research salaries for senior roles in your field

– Emphasize leadership skills and industry knowledge

– Be prepared to justify higher salary requests with concrete examples of your value

When discussing salary, you might say:

Entry-level: “As someone new to the field, I’m excited to learn and grow. I’ve researched starting salaries for this role and understand they typically range from [X] to [Y]. Is this in line with what you’re offering?”

Mid-level: “With [X] years of experience in this field, including [specific achievement], I believe a salary in the range of [Y] to [Z] would be appropriate. How does this align with your expectations for someone at my experience level?”

Experienced: “Given my [X] years of experience and track record of [specific achievements], I’m looking for a salary in the range of [Y] to [Z]. This reflects the value I can bring to the role from day one. How does this fit with your budget for this position?”

Remember:

• Be realistic about what your experience is worth

• Don’t undersell yourself if you have valuable skills

• Consider the whole package, not just salary

• Be ready to explain how your experience adds value

As you gain experience, regularly reassess your market value. This helps you know when it’s time to ask for a raise or seek new opportunities that match your growing skills.

How Location Impacts Salary Expectations

Where a job is located can have a big effect on salary. This is because the cost of living and job market are different in different places. Here’s how location impacts salary:

• Big cities usually have higher salaries because living there costs more

• Rural areas often have lower salaries, but living costs are usually lower too

• Some cities are known for certain industries and may pay more for those jobs

• States and countries have different minimum wages and labor laws

Things to consider about location:

1. Cost of living:

– Housing costs

– Food and transportation expenses

– Taxes (which can be very different in different places)

2. Job market:

– How many similar jobs are available

– How many people are looking for those jobs

– If there’s a shortage of workers with your skills

3. Industry presence:

– Some areas have more companies in certain industries

– This can lead to more job options and sometimes higher pay

4. Remote work:

– More jobs now allow working from anywhere

– This can affect how location impacts salary

When discussing salary and location, you might say:

“I’ve researched salaries for this role in [city/area], and they typically range from [X] to [Y]. Given the cost of living here, I believe a salary in the [specific range] would be fair. Does this align with your salary range for this position?”

If you’re moving for a job:

“I understand that salaries in [new location] might be different from where I currently live. Can you help me understand how your offer takes into account the local cost of living?”

For remote work:

“Even though this is a remote position, I’m based in [your location] where the cost of living is [high/low]. How does your company approach salary for remote workers in different locations?”

Remember:

• Always research salaries specific to your location

• Consider the whole picture – a lower salary in a cheaper area might be worth more

• Be prepared to explain why your location should factor into your salary

• For remote jobs, understand the company’s policy on location-based pay

Understanding how location affects salary helps you negotiate better and make informed decisions about job offers, especially if you’re considering moving for work.

Company Size and Salary Considerations

The size of a company can have a big impact on the salaries they offer. Here’s how company size typically affects pay:

• Large companies often pay more because they have bigger budgets

• Small companies might offer lower salaries but could have other benefits

• Mid-size companies usually fall somewhere in between

Here’s a closer look at how company size impacts salary:

Large Companies (500+ employees):

– Often have set salary ranges for each position

– Might offer better benefits packages

– Usually have more room for career growth

– May have annual salary increases and bonuses

– Often have more resources for training and development

Small Companies (fewer than 50 employees):

– Might offer lower base salaries

– Could provide equity or profit-sharing instead

– May have more flexible work arrangements

– Often give employees more responsibilities, which can lead to faster skill development

– Might have a more personal work environment

Mid-size Companies (50-500 employees):

– Often try to balance competitive salaries with other benefits

– May have more flexibility in salary negotiations

– Could offer a mix of big company benefits and small company culture

When considering a job offer, think about:

1. Total compensation: Look beyond just the salary. Consider bonuses, stock options, and benefits.

2. Growth potential: Smaller companies might offer faster advancement opportunities.

3. Work-life balance: Larger companies might have more structured hours, while smaller ones could be more flexible.

4. Job security: Larger companies might offer more stability, but smaller ones could provide more job satisfaction.

5. Learning opportunities: In smaller companies, you might wear many hats and learn diverse skills.

When discussing salary with companies of different sizes, you could say:

For a large company: “I understand that [Company Name], as a large organization, likely has established salary ranges. Could you share the range for this position? I’m also interested in learning about the overall benefits package and growth opportunities within the company.”

For a small company: “I’m excited about the opportunity to work with a growing company like [Company Name]. While I understand that salaries in smaller companies might differ from larger corporations, I’m interested in the overall compensation package, including any equity or profit-sharing options. Could you tell me more about how you approach compensation?”

For a mid-size company: “I’m curious about how [Company Name] approaches compensation, being a mid-size company. Could you share the salary range for this position and tell me more about other benefits or perks that might be part of the total package?”

Remember, there’s no one-size-fits-all when it comes to company size and salary. Each company, regardless of size, will have its own approach to compensation. It’s important to consider what matters most to you in a job – whether that’s a high salary, work-life balance, growth opportunities, or a combination of factors.

Also, keep in mind that company size doesn’t always directly correlate with salary. Some small companies in high-growth industries might offer very competitive salaries, while some large companies in more traditional industries might have more modest pay scales.

The key is to do your research, understand the company’s position in the market, and be clear about your own priorities. This will help you navigate salary discussions effectively, regardless of the company’s size.

Economic Factors Affecting Salaries

The overall economy plays a big role in determining salaries. Understanding these economic factors can help you set realistic salary expectations and negotiate better. Here are some key economic factors that affect salaries:

1. Inflation: As the cost of living goes up, salaries often increase to keep pace. When discussing salary, you might say, “I’ve taken into account the current inflation rate of X% when considering my salary expectations.”

2. Supply and Demand: When there are more jobs than qualified workers, salaries tend to go up. If there are more workers than jobs, salaries might go down. You could mention, “I understand that there’s currently a high demand for [your skill] in the job market, which is reflected in my salary expectations.”

3. Industry Growth: Fast-growing industries often offer higher salaries to attract talent. You might say, “Given the rapid growth in [your industry], I believe my salary expectations are in line with current market trends.”

4. Company Performance: Companies doing well financially can often offer better salaries. If you know the company is performing well, you could say, “I’ve read about [Company’s] strong performance this year, and I’m excited about the possibility of contributing to that success.”

5. Economic Recessions or Booms: During tough economic times, salaries might stagnate or even decrease. In good times, they often increase. You might need to adjust your expectations based on the current economic climate.

6. Globalization: This can affect salaries as companies might compare wages globally. For some roles, this could mean competing with lower-wage countries, while for others, it might mean access to higher-paying international jobs.

7. Technology Changes: New technologies can make some jobs obsolete while creating high-paying opportunities in new fields. Staying up-to-date with technology in your field can help you command higher salaries.

8. Government Policies: Things like minimum wage laws, tax policies, and labor regulations can all impact salaries. Being aware of these can help you understand the broader context of salary discussions.

9. Cost of Living: This varies greatly by location and directly impacts how far a salary will go. You might say, “I’ve researched the cost of living in [City] and factored this into my salary expectations.”

10. Exchange Rates: For international jobs or companies, currency exchange rates can affect the real value of a salary. This is important to consider if you’re looking at jobs in different countries.

When discussing salary, it’s good to show that you’re aware of these factors. You could say something like, “I’ve considered current economic trends, including [specific factor], in determining my salary expectations. I believe a range of [X] to [Y] is fair and competitive in the current market.”

Remember, economic factors can change quickly. What was a competitive salary last year might not be this year. It’s important to stay informed about economic trends in your industry and location. Regularly updating your knowledge will help you make informed decisions about your career and negotiate effectively.

Also, keep in mind that while these economic factors affect overall salary trends, your individual skills, experience, and the specific value you bring to a company are still crucial in determining your personal salary. Be prepared to discuss how your unique contributions justify your salary expectations, regardless of broader economic trends.

Balancing Salary with Career Growth Potential

When considering a job offer, it’s important to look beyond just the salary. Career growth potential can be just as valuable, if not more so, in the long run. Here’s how to balance salary with career growth opportunities:

1. Look at the big picture: A lower-paying job with great learning opportunities might lead to higher-paying roles in the future. When discussing this with an employer, you could say, “While the salary is important to me, I’m also very interested in the growth opportunities this position offers. Could you tell me more about potential career paths within the company?”

2. Consider skill development: Some jobs offer training or the chance to learn new skills. These can be valuable for your future career. You might ask, “Does the company offer any professional development programs or opportunities to learn new skills?”

3. Evaluate promotion potential: A company with a clear path for advancement might be worth considering, even if the starting salary is lower. You could inquire, “What does the typical career progression look like for someone in this role?”

4. Look at the industry trajectory: Some industries are growing faster than others. A job in a growing field might offer more opportunities for advancement. You might say, “I’m excited about the growth in this industry. How do you see this role evolving as the industry changes?”

5. Consider company growth: Fast-growing companies often provide more opportunities for career advancement. You could ask, “I’ve read about the company’s growth plans. How might this growth create new opportunities for employees?”

6. Assess the work environment: A positive work culture that encourages learning and growth can be very valuable. You might inquire, “Can you tell me more about the company culture, particularly how it supports employee growth and development?”

7. Look at networking opportunities: Some jobs offer chances to meet influential people in your field. This can be great for long-term career growth. You could ask, “Does this role involve working with other departments or external partners?”

8. Consider work-life balance: A job that allows you to have a life outside of work can contribute to your overall career satisfaction and prevent burnout. You might say, “I’m interested in understanding how the company supports work-life balance for its employees.”

9. Evaluate the company’s reputation: Working for a well-respected company can boost your resume and lead to better opportunities later. You could mention, “I’m impressed by the company’s reputation in the industry. How do you think working here might benefit my long-term career goals?”

10. Look at the whole compensation package: Benefits like health insurance, retirement plans, and paid time off can add significant value beyond your salary. You might ask, “Could you provide more details about the full compensation package, including benefits and any performance-based bonuses?”

When negotiating, you could say something like, “While the salary is slightly lower than I was hoping for, I’m very interested in the growth opportunities this position offers. Would it be possible to discuss a performance review in six months, with the potential for a salary adjustment based on my contributions?”

Remember, it’s okay to prioritize growth over salary, especially early in your career. You might say, “At this stage in my career, I’m particularly focused on roles that will help me develop my skills and advance in the field. This position seems to offer excellent growth potential, which is very appealing to me.”

However, don’t undervalue yourself. If you’re taking a lower salary for growth potential, make sure the opportunity is really there. You could ask for specific examples of how previous employees in this role have grown and advanced within the company.

Ultimately, the right balance between salary and growth potential will depend on your individual circumstances, career goals, and financial needs. Be honest with yourself about what you need now and what you’re willing to invest in your future career. And remember, it’s not just about choosing between salary and growth – the best opportunities often offer a good mix of both.

Legal Considerations in Salary Discussions

When discussing salary, it’s important to be aware of legal considerations. These laws are designed to promote fair pay practices and prevent discrimination. Here are some key legal points to keep in mind:

1. Salary History Bans: Many states and cities have laws that prohibit employers from asking about your salary history. This is to prevent past pay discrimination from following you to new jobs. If an employer asks about your past salary in a place where it’s illegal, you could say, “I understand that discussing salary history isn’t permitted under local law. I’d be happy to discuss my salary expectations for this role based on its responsibilities and my qualifications.”

2. Pay Equity Laws: These laws require equal pay for equal work, regardless of gender, race, or other protected characteristics. If you believe you’re being offered less due to discrimination, you have the right to address this. You might say, “I’m curious about how the company ensures pay equity across similar roles.”

3. Minimum Wage Laws: Every state has minimum wage laws, and some cities have even higher minimums. Make sure you’re aware of the minimum wage in your area. You could ask, “Can you confirm that this salary meets or exceeds all applicable minimum wage laws?”

4. Overtime Pay: Many employees are entitled to overtime pay for hours worked over 40 per week. If you’re in a role that might involve overtime, you could ask, “How does the company handle compensation for overtime work?”

5. Non-Disclosure Agreements: Some companies ask employees not to discuss their salaries. However, in many cases, this is not legally enforceable. The National Labor Relations Act protects most employees’ right to discuss pay with coworkers.

6. Salary Transparency Laws: Some states require employers to disclose salary ranges for job postings. If you’re in such a state and don’t see a range, you could ask, “I noticed the job posting didn’t include a salary range. Could you provide that information as required by local law?”

7. Contract Work vs. Employee Status: The law treats these differently in terms of minimum wage, overtime, and benefits. If you’re unclear about your status, you might ask, “Can you clarify whether this is a W-2 employee position or a 1099 contractor role?”

8. Signing Bonuses and Relocation Expenses: If these are offered, make sure you understand any obligations they come with. You could ask, “Are there any conditions attached to the signing bonus or relocation expenses, such as a minimum employment period?”

9. Benefits and Leave Policies: Some benefits are legally required, like family and medical leave. You might inquire, “Can you tell me about the company’s leave policies and how they align with state and federal requirements?”

10. Negotiation Protection: It’s illegal for an employer to retaliate against you for negotiating your salary. This is protected under the National Labor Relations Act.

When discussing these topics, you could say something like, “I want to ensure our salary discussion complies with all relevant laws. Are there any legal considerations I should be aware of as we continue this conversation?”

Remember, while it’s good to be aware of these laws, you don’t need to be a legal expert. If you’re unsure about your rights or feel that an employer might be violating labor laws, it’s okay to say, “I’d like to take some time to review this offer and ensure I understand all the legal aspects. When can we continue our discussion?”

It’s also important to note that labor laws can vary significantly by country, state, and even city. What’s legal in one place might not be in another. If you’re job hunting in a new area or industry, it might be worth researching the specific laws that apply there.

Lastly, if you encounter what you believe to be illegal practices during your job search or salary negotiations, consider seeking advice from a labor lawyer or your local department of labor. Your rights are important, and understanding the legal aspects of salary discussions can help you negotiate more effectively and ensure you’re treated fairly in the workplace.

How Remote Work is Changing Salary Expectations

The rise of remote work is significantly impacting how companies approach salaries and how job seekers think about compensation. This shift is creating new considerations for both employers and employees. Here’s how remote work is changing salary expectations:

1. Location-Based Pay: Some companies are adjusting salaries based on where employees live, rather than where the company is based. You might ask, “Does the company have a policy on adjusting salaries for remote workers based on their location?”

2. Expanded Talent Pool: Companies can now hire from anywhere, potentially affecting salary competitiveness. You could say, “I’m curious how the company determines competitive salaries given the ability to hire talent from various locations.”

3. Cost Savings for Employees: Remote work can save money on commuting, work clothes, and meals out. This might affect salary negotiations. You could mention, “I’ve considered the cost savings of working remotely in my salary expectations.”

4. Home Office Stipends: Many companies offer allowances for home office setup. You might ask, “Does the company provide any stipend or reimbursement for home office expenses?”

5. Flexible Hours: Some remote jobs offer more flexible schedules, which could be seen as a non-monetary benefit. You could inquire, “How does the company approach work hours and flexibility for remote employees?”

6. Technology Allowances: Remote work often requires specific technology. You might ask, “Is there a policy on providing or reimbursing for necessary technology for remote work?”

7. Travel Expectations: Some remote jobs require occasional travel to a main office. You could ask, “Are there any in-person work requirements, and if so, how is travel compensated?”

8. Performance Metrics: Remote work often focuses more on output than hours worked. You might say, “I’m interested in understanding how performance is measured and rewarded in a remote setting.”

9. Global Competition: Remote work opens up global job markets, potentially affecting salary scales. You could ask, “How does the company approach salary competitiveness in a global remote work environment?”

10. Work-Life Balance: Remote work can blur the lines between work and personal life. You might inquire, “How does the company support work-life balance for remote employees?”

When discussing remote work and salary, you could say something like, “I’m excited about the opportunity to work remotely. I’ve researched salary trends for remote positions in my field and location. Based on this, and considering the unique aspects of remote work, I believe a salary range of [X] to [Y] would be appropriate. How does this align with your compensation structure for remote employees?”

It’s also important to consider the long-term implications of remote work on your career. You might ask, “How does the company ensure remote workers have equal opportunities for career advancement and salary growth compared to in-office employees?”

Remember, remote work policies and their impact on salaries are still evolving. Many companies are still figuring out their long-term strategies. It’s okay to ask for clarity on policies that might affect your compensation now or in the future.

Additionally, consider how remote work might affect your overall compensation package. Some companies might offer lower salaries but better benefits or more flexibility. Others might pay more but have stricter work-from-home policies. Think about what’s most important to you in a remote work arrangement.

Lastly, be prepared for the possibility that some companies might use remote work as a reason to offer lower salaries, citing cost savings for the employee. In such cases, you might respond by highlighting the value you bring to the role, regardless of where you’re working from. You could say, “While I understand that remote work can offer some cost savings, I believe my skills and experience bring significant value to this role. I’m confident that my contributions will justify a competitive salary in line with industry standards for this position.”

As remote work continues to shape the job market, staying informed about trends in remote work compensation will be crucial for effective salary negotiations. Keep researching and networking to understand how your industry and potential employers are approaching remote work and compensation.

Conclusion

Answering the desired salary question requires careful preparation and strategy. By researching salary ranges, considering your experience level, and understanding how factors like location and company size impact pay, you can approach salary discussions with confidence.

Remember to look beyond just the base salary and consider the total compensation package, including benefits and growth opportunities. Be prepared to justify your salary expectations based on the value you bring to the role. With the right approach, you can navigate salary negotiations successfully and secure fair compensation that aligns with your skills and career goals.

How Was The US Flag On The Moon 55 Years Ago? Here's What Scientists Say

Every Apollo mission, the astronauts always raised the US flag on the surface of the Moon.

How Was The US Flag On The Moon 55 Years Ago? Here's What Scientists Say

55 years ago, when Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin landed on the Moon, they raised the American flag during the Apollo 11 mission. 

It took them 10 minutes to raise the flag while they walked on the Moon's surface for 2.5 hours in July 1969.

In addition to the flag planted during the Apollo 11 mission, there were also several American flags raised by other astronauts during the Apollo 17 mission.

The question is, is the flag still waving to this day and what is its condition?














How Was The US Flag On The Moon 55 Years Ago?

Even though the flags still flutter as the ship's crew launches from the moon. 

It can be almost certain that its condition is not the same as when it was first deployed on the surface of the moon.

"The likelihood is that the nylon material on the flag has degraded due to prolonged exposure to sunlight," explained Anne Platoff, a librarian, historian, and vexillology expert at the University of California, Santa Barbara.

Vexillology is the study of the history, symbolism, and usage of flags.

Another threat that can damage the flag is the impact of meteoroid strikes on the moon.

Platoff explained that the moon flag is likely to become brittle and may eventually disintegrate over time. 

"One thing I always see in articles is that the flag will fade due to exposure to sunlight. Although this happens to some flags on Earth, I am not sure about the chemical process involved and whether this will happen in the lunar environment," Platoff explained to Space.com.

As Platoff wrote in his research paper in 2011, "Six Flags over Luna: The Role of Flags in Moon Landing Conspiracy Theories," whether the flag remains standing or has experienced harsh lunar environmental exposure for decades, he states that "their legacy as a symbol of human space exploration remains intact."

He also added that the flag will endure long after the death of those who participated in the historic endeavor. As for those who support the conspiracy of the Apollo moon landing being faked, Platoff insists on the matter.

"Denying the moon landing conspiracy hoaxes is not difficult to do," Platoff explained.

"There is a lot of evidence out there that proves that the Apollo landing is real and humans have walked on the surface of the moon."

The real problem, added Platoff, is the need to educate society to become critical thinkers.

Platoff conveyed that people who deny the Apollo landing on the moon actually happened, "are free to believe what they want, but that doesn't make them right."

How Was The US Flag On The Moon 55 Years Ago?

30 Being Alone Quotes: Powerful Phrases to Find Strength in Solitude

These quotes reminds us that being alone does not mean feeling lonely.

30 Being Alone Quotes: Powerful Phrases to Find Strength in Solitude

Being alone can sometimes be difficult. But there is a positive side, too.

This article is about being alone quotes that find kindness in spending time alone. These quotes show how much strength and peace you can see in aloneness.

Being alone quotes aim to inspire loneliness, from expressing the peace that comes from spending time alone to exploring the growth.

These quotes reminds us that being alone does not mean feeling lonely.

Let's start looking for powerful loneliness quotes together.

Discover the beauty of enjoying our own togetherness.

trstdly © 2024

  • “I love to be alone. I never found the companion that was so companionable as solitude.” – Henry David Thoreau
  • “In order to be open to creativity, one must have the capacity for constructive use of solitude. One must overcome the fear of being alone.” – Rollo May
  • “The best thinking has been done in solitude. The worst has been done in turmoil.” – Thomas A. Edison
  • “Solitude is the soul’s holiday, an opportunity to stop doing for others and to surprise and delight ourselves instead.” – Katrina Kenison
  • “I restore myself when I’m alone.” – Marilyn Monroe

  • "Alone time is when I discover all the powerful dreams hiding within me." - Robin Sharma
  • “In solitude, where we are least alone.” – Lord Byron
  • “The soul that sees beauty may sometimes walk alone.” – Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
  • “The greatest thing in the world is to know how to belong to oneself.” – Michel de Montaigne
  • “I think it’s very healthy to spend time alone. You need to know how to be alone and not be defined by another person.” – Oscar Wilde

Being Alone Quotes to Inspire Self-Discovery and Growth

  • “Alone had always felt like an actual place to me, as if it weren’t a state of being, but rather a room where I could retreat to be who I really was.” – Cheryl Strayed
  • “If you are alone you belong entirely to yourself. If you are accompanied by even one companion you belong only half to yourself or even less in proportion to the thoughtlessness of his conduct.” – Leonardo da Vinci
  • “Alone time is when I distance myself from the voices of the world so I can hear my own.” – Oprah Winfrey
  • “When we cannot bear to be alone, it means we do not properly value the only companion we will have from birth to death – ourselves.” – Eda J. LeShan

  • “In solitude, we discover that what we need most isn’t answers, but the ability to question and challenge our own assumptions.” – Mark Nepo
  • "I live in that solitude which is painful in youth, but delicious in the years of maturity." - Albert Einstein
  • "Being alone has a power very few can handle." - Steven Aitchison
  • "Sometimes, you find yourself in the middle of nowhere, and sometimes, in the middle of nowhere, you find yourself." - Unknown
  • "To go out with the setting sun on an empty beach is to truly embrace your solitude." - Jeanne Moreau

  • "All men's miseries derive from not being able to sit in a quiet room alone." - Blaise Pascal

Being Alone Quotes to Bring Peace

  • “We need quiet time to examine our lives openly and honestly. Spending quiet time alone gives your mind an opportunity to renew itself and create order.” – Susan L. Taylor
  • “The quieter you become, the more you can hear.” – Ram Dass
  • “The loneliness you get by the sea is personal and alive. It doesn’t subdue you and make you feel abject. It’s stimulating loneliness.” – Anne Morrow Lindbergh
  • “Your relationship with yourself sets the tone for every other relationship you have.” – Robert Holden

  • “Solitude is where I place my chaos to rest and awaken my inner peace.” – Nikki Rowe
  • "Being alone is not the absence of company, it's the moment we face ourselves and find peace within." - Anonymous
  • "Alone time is when I turn my mind off and let my heart breathe." - Anonymous
  • "Within yourself is a stillness, a sanctuary to which you can retreat at any time and be yourself." - Hermann Hesse
  • "Peace can be found in no one but ourselves and in our solitude." - Hermann Hesse
  • "In the inner solitude of the heart, we find peace and profound clarity." - Anonymous.

Here Are 5 Zodiacs You Should Never Mess With!

Astrology often highlights positive traits and compatibility, but it can also delve into the darker aspects of each sign.

Here Are 5 Zodiacs You Should Never Mess With!

Scorpio (October 23 - November 21)

If wronged, they are relentless and can orchestrate elaborate schemes to settle scores.Their ability to dig deep into others' weaknesses makes them particularly dangerous.

Traits:

Vengeful: Scorpios are known for their intense and unyielding nature. They hold grudges and seek revenge meticulously.

Manipulative: Highly perceptive, Scorpios can manipulate situations and people to their advantage, often without the other party realizing it.

Secretive: They keep their true intentions hidden, making it hard to predict their next move.

Capricorn (December 22 - January 19)

If you stand in their way, they won’t hesitate to remove you as an obstacle. Their calculated and methodical approach can make them formidable opponents.

Traits:

Ruthless: Ambitious and driven, Capricorns will stop at nothing to achieve their goals, sometimes at the expense of others.

Cold: They can be emotionally detached and pragmatic, often appearing unsympathetic and harsh.

Controlling: Capricorns have a strong need to be in control, which can make them domineering and overbearing.

Gemini (May 21 - June 20)

Geminis' unpredictable nature and duality can make them dangerous. They can switch sides or betray trust without warning, leaving others blindsided by their actions.

Traits:

Two-Faced: Geminis are often labeled as two-faced due to their dual nature. They can be charming and deceitful at the same time.

Unpredictable: Their moods and intentions can change rapidly, making them unreliable and capricious.

Manipulative: Their communication skills are top-notch, which they can use to deceive and manipulate others.

Leo (July 23 - August 22)

Leos can be extremely vindictive if they feel disrespected or overshadowed. Their need for control and dominance can make them overbearing and ruthless adversaries.

Traits:

Egoistic: Leos have a strong sense of self-importance and crave admiration, which can lead to arrogance and condescension.

Domineering: They like to be the center of attention and can become aggressive if their authority is challenged.

Vindictive: If their pride is hurt, Leos can become very vengeful and will go to great lengths to restore their dignity.

Virgo (August 23 - September 22)

Virgos' critical nature and perfectionism can make them harsh and unforgiving. If you cross them, they are capable of devising meticulous plans to retaliate, making them formidable opponents.

Critical: Virgos are perfectionists and can be overly critical and judgmental of others.

Obsessive: Their attention to detail can border on obsessive, leading them to nitpick and control situations excessively.

Vindictive: When wronged, Virgos can become highly vindictive, using their analytical skills to plot intricate revenge.

6 Recommended French Movies For You and Where to Watch!

Here are 6 French movies that you must watch and where to watch them.

6 Recommended French Movies For You and Where to Watch!

Apart from being known for its food, romantic aura, and football, France is also known for having many famous movie titles.

French movies are known to have high artistic value and interesting story quality.

Here are 6 French movies that you must watch and where to watch them.

Directed by François Truffaut, "The 400 Blows" is a seminal film of the French New Wave movement. It follows the story of Antoine Doinel, a young boy growing up in Paris, as he navigates the challenges of adolescence and rebellion. The film offers a poignant portrayal of youth and societal pressures, capturing the essence of alienation and longing for freedom. You can watch it on various streaming platforms like Criterion Channel or Kanopy.

The 400 Blows/Les Quatre Cents Coups (1959)

Directed by Jean-Pierre Jeunet, "Amélie" is a whimsical romantic comedy set in Paris. The film tells the story of a shy and imaginative young woman named Amélie who decides to secretly improve the lives of those around her while struggling with her own quest for love and connection. With its charming visuals, quirky characters, and heartfelt narrative, "Amélie" has become a beloved classic. It's available for streaming on platforms like Netflix or Amazon Prime Video.

Amelie (2001)

Directed by Jean-Luc Godard, "Breathless" is another iconic film from the French New Wave movement. It follows the story of a small-time thief named Michel who impulsively kills a policeman and seeks refuge with his American girlfriend, Patricia. Shot in a groundbreaking and experimental style, "Breathless" is celebrated for its innovative cinematography and existential themes. You can watch it on platforms like The Criterion Channel or Kanopy.

Breathless / À Bout de Souffle (1960)

Directed by Mathieu Kassovitz, "La Haine" (which translates to "Hate") is a gritty and powerful drama set in the impoverished suburbs of Paris. The film chronicles 24 hours in the lives of three young men from immigrant families as they navigate racial tensions, police brutality, and social unrest. With its raw realism and intense performances, "La Haine" remains a potent commentary on urban alienation and societal injustice. It's available for streaming on platforms like Amazon Prime Video or Google Play Movies.

Le Haine (1995)

Directed by Olivier Nakache and Éric Toledano, "The Intouchables" is a heartwarming comedy-drama inspired by the true story of a wealthy quadriplegic and his unlikely friendship with his caregiver, a young man from the projects. The film explores themes of friendship, empathy, and the transformative power of human connection with humor and sensitivity. "The Intouchables" became a massive international success and is available for streaming on platforms like Netflix or Hulu.

The Intouchables (2011)

Directed by Jean Renoir, "The Rules of the Game" is a classic of French cinema and widely regarded as one of the greatest films ever made. Set against the backdrop of a lavish country estate, the film satirizes the moral decay and hypocrisy of the French aristocracy on the eve of World War II. With its ensemble cast, intricate plot, and layered social commentary, "The Rules of the Game" is a masterpiece of filmmaking. You can watch it on platforms like The Criterion Channel or Kanopy.

The Rules of The Game (1939)

6 Places to Visit in Toulouse, France, That Will Leave You in Awe

6 Places to Visit in Toulouse, France, That Will Leave You in Awe

If you're planning a trip to Toulouse, France, you're in for a treat!

This beautiful city is filled with stunning architecture, fascinating history, and a rich culture that will leave you in awe. Here are some of the best places to visit in Toulouse that you definitely don't want to miss:

The Basilique Saint-Sernin is a stunning Romanesque church that dates back to the 11th century. It is the largest Romanesque church in Europe and is known for its beautiful architecture and impressive size.

1. Basilique Saint-Sernin

Take a stroll through the interior to admire the intricate carvings and stained glass windows, or simply marvel at the grandeur of the exterior.

2. Le Capitole

Le Capitole is the city hall of Toulouse and is located in the heart of the city. The building itself is a sight to behold, with its striking pink facade and grandiose architecture.

Inside, you'll find several museums, including the Salle des Illustres, which features stunning frescoes and paintings.

Be sure to take a walk around the beautiful square in front of the building, where you can enjoy street performers and outdoor cafes.

3. Cathédrale Saint-Etienne

The Cathédrale Saint-Etienne is a beautiful Gothic cathedral that dates back to the 13th century. The cathedral is known for its stunning stained glass windows, intricate carvings, and impressive organ.

Take a tour around the cathedral to learn more about its fascinating history and admire the intricate details that make it a must-see attraction in Toulouse.

4. Musée des Augustins

The Musée des Augustins is a former convent turned art museum that houses a collection of European paintings and sculptures from the Middle Ages to the early 20th century.

It's also one of the oldest museums in France. The museum is home to works by famous artists such as Toulouse-Lautrec, Delacroix, and Rubens.

Spend a few hours wandering the halls of this impressive museum and admiring the beautiful art on display.

If you're a fan of space and science, the Cité de l'Espace is a must-visit attraction in Toulouse.

5. Cité de l'Espace

This interactive space museum features exhibits on space exploration, the history of space travel, and even a full-size model of a space station.

Don't miss the planetarium shows and outdoor exhibitions, where you can learn more about the wonders of the universe.

6. Couvent des Jacobins

The Couvent des Jacobins is a former Dominican convent that dates back to the 13th century. The convent is known for its stunning architecture, including a beautiful cloister and the impressive Church of the Jacobins. 

Take a guided tour to learn more about the history of the convent and admire the intricate details of this historical site.

-- Batch 11\r\nSELECT * FROM scraped_art.title: How to Tie Dye Shirts: A Step-by-Step Guide
-- Batch 11\r\nSELECT * FROM scraped_art.meta_description: Find out how to tie dye shirts and transform simple white clothes into eye-catching pieces.
-- Batch 11\r\nSELECT * FROM scraped_art.meta_keywords: how to tie dye shirts,tie dye,tips to tie dye shirts
-- Batch 11\r\nSELECT * FROM scraped_art.content:
How to Tie Dye Shirts: A Step-by-Step Guide

Learning how to tie dye shirts is one of the most fun and creative activities you can do at home. This colorful craft has been popular for many years and never goes out of style. With just a few simple materials and some patience, you can turn plain white shirts into beautiful rainbow masterpieces that everyone will love.

Tie dyeing is a method of coloring fabric by folding, twisting, or binding it in different ways before adding dye. The tied areas resist the dye, creating unique patterns and designs. This technique works best on natural fabrics like cotton because they absorb the colors well and hold them for a long time.

In this guide, you will discover everything you need to know about how to tie dye shirts successfully. We gathered this guide from various sources, Wednesday (2/7/2025).

How to Tie Dye Shirts: A Step-by-Step Guide

Creating beautiful tie-dyed shirts is easier than you might think when you follow the right steps. This method will help you make colorful designs that look professional and last through many washes.

Step 1: Choose Your Shirt and Prepare It

Start with a 100% cotton shirt for the best results. Cotton absorbs dye much better than synthetic materials like polyester. If you use a shirt that is 50% cotton and 50% polyester, the colors will not be as bright. Always wash your shirt first to remove any chemicals or sizing that might prevent the dye from sticking properly. After washing, leave the shirt damp but not dripping wet.

Step 2: Gather Your Supplies

You will need rubber bands, squeeze bottles, plastic gloves, dye powder or liquid dye, soda ash, paper towels, and plastic to protect your work area. Many craft stores sell complete tie-dye kits that include everything you need. These kits are perfect for beginners because they come with easy instructions and pre-measured amounts of each chemical.

Step 3: Set Up Your Work Space

Cover your work surface with plastic tablecloth or large trash bags. Tie dyeing can be messy, so protect everything around you. Wear old clothes that you do not mind getting stained. The dye will permanently color anything it touches, including your skin, so always wear plastic gloves.

Step 4: Soak the Shirt in Soda Ash

Mix soda ash with warm water according to the package directions. Soak your damp shirt in this solution for about 10 minutes. The soda ash helps the dye bond strongly with the fabric. Add a few tablespoons of salt to the mixture for even better results. After soaking, wring out the shirt well but do not rinse it.

Step 5: Create Your Design

Place the shirt on a flat surface and decide what pattern you want. For a spiral design, pinch the center of the shirt and twist it clockwise until it forms a flat circle. Secure this shape with several rubber bands that cross over each other. For stripes, fold the shirt like an accordion and wrap rubber bands around it at regular spaces.

Step 6: Mix Your Dyes

Follow the instructions on your dye package to mix the colors. Use warm water, not hot water, as hot water can damage some dyes. Shake the bottles well until all the powder dissolves completely. You can use the mixed dye for up to 48 hours, but it works best when fresh.

Step 7: Apply the Dye

Place your tied shirt on paper towels to catch drips. Hold the dye bottle close to the fabric and squeeze the dye into the folds. Make sure the dye reaches all layers of fabric. For a rainbow spiral, divide your shirt into three sections and use different colors for each part. Yellow and red will mix to create orange, while blue and yellow make green.

Step 8: Flip and Repeat

Turn your shirt over and apply dye to the other side. Use the same colors in the same places to keep your pattern clear. If you put different colors on opposite sides, you will get a mixed effect that might look muddy.

Step 9: Let the Dye Set

Put your dyed shirt in a plastic bag and seal it tightly. Place the bag in a warm spot and wait for at least 12 to 24 hours. The longer you wait, the brighter your colors will be. The heat and moisture help the dye bond with the fabric permanently.

Step 10: Rinse and Wash

After the waiting time, put on gloves and take the shirt out of the bag. Rinse it under cold water while still tied up. Then cut off the rubber bands and continue rinsing until the water runs clear. This might take several minutes. Finally, wash the shirt alone in your washing machine with mild detergent.

What You Can Tie Dye

Tie dyeing works on many different items made from natural fibers. You are not limited to just shirts when exploring this creative hobby.

Cotton clothing items work wonderfully for tie dyeing projects. T-shirts, tank tops, dresses, and even socks can be transformed with beautiful colors. Bandanas and scarves made from cotton or silk create stunning accessories that add personality to any outfit. These smaller items are also great for practicing new techniques.

Home decor items offer another exciting opportunity for tie dyeing. Pillowcases, sheets, and curtains can bring bright colors into your living space. Table runners and cloth napkins make unique pieces for special dinners. Even canvas tote bags become artistic statement pieces when tie-dyed with your favorite colors.

Other natural fiber materials also work well with this technique. Silk scarves create elegant results with smooth, flowing colors. Rayon fabrics produce bright, vibrant results similar to cotton. Hemp and linen materials also accept dye well, though they may require longer soaking times for the best color absorption.

Tips to Get the Perfect Result

These helpful tips will ensure your tie-dye projects turn out beautiful every time. Following these guidelines will help you avoid common mistakes and create professional-looking results.

- Use Natural Fabrics: Cotton, silk, rayon, and other natural materials work best for tie dyeing. Avoid synthetic fabrics like polyester, spandex, or lycra because they will not hold the dye properly and your colors will wash out quickly.

- Keep Fabric Damp: Start with damp fabric, not completely dry or soaking wet. Damp fabric allows the dye to spread evenly while still maintaining clear pattern lines. If your fabric gets too dry during the process, mist it lightly with a spray bottle.

- Tie Tightly: Make sure your rubber bands or ties are very tight. Loose ties will allow dye to seep into areas where you want white space, creating blurry patterns instead of crisp designs. Wet fabric expands, so tie even tighter than you think necessary.

- Mind Your Color Choices: Understand basic color mixing to avoid muddy results. Keep similar colors together and avoid placing opposite colors next to each other. Red next to green, blue next to orange, or yellow next to purple will create brown or gray areas.

- Apply Enough Dye: Use plenty of dye to get rich, vibrant colors. Squeeze the dye deep into the folds to make sure it reaches all layers of fabric. However, avoid creating puddles that will cause colors to bleed into unwanted areas.

- Be Patient with Setting Time: Never rush the setting process. Let your tied fabric sit for the full recommended time, usually 12 to 24 hours. This waiting period allows the chemical reaction to complete and ensures your colors will be permanent and bright.

- Rinse Properly: Start rinsing with cold water to prevent colors from bleeding. Only remove the ties after the initial rinse. Continue rinsing until the water runs completely clear, then wash the item separately for the first few washes.

Philippine Airport Officer Caught on Camera Swallowing $300 Stolen Money

Philippine Airport Officer Caught on Camera Swallowing $300 Stolen Money

A scanning officer at Manila International Airport in the Philippines sparked online outrage after she was seen swallowing cash stolen from a passenger's wallet in a video.

An airport security camera footage shows the officer swallowing a $300 note into her mouth. The airport officer was identified as Irency Morados.

She was seen drinking water from a bottle by an airport body scanner operator named Regino Allen.

Her supervisor, Abraham de Luna, was also seen talking to Officer Morados, as she appeared to choke on the bill while covering her mouth with a handkerchief.

A report from the Philippines' Office of Transportation Security (OTS) suggested that the money came from a passenger's wallet.

The wallet was taken from a sling bag given to Morados before the passenger underwent a full body scan.

After a while, the passenger realized that her wallet was open and the money inside was missing.

She then complained to people in the screening area.

That's when Morados turned around and started swallowing the bills to avoid being caught, OTS said in its report.

However, when she put the money in her mouth, the female officer did not realize she was turning towards the security camera.

As reported by Asia One, Morados' boss, De Luna, is suspected of being involved in this scandal.

He approached Morados to ensure the banknotes were sent to avoid evidence. On Thursday, September 21, 2023, Philippine airport authorities ordered that charges be filed against Morados.

The incident occurred on September 8. Philippine Transportation Secretary Jaime Bautista said his office is seeking the maximum penalty against Morados.

Online news site Rappler reported that this was the third highly publicized theft incident at Manila Airport in 2023.

Horse Quotes: 30 Insightful Words to Describe the Beauty of Horses

Horse Quotes: 30 Insightful Words to Describe the Beauty of Horses 

The horse is not just an animal. They are symbols of strength, freedom, and beauty. They have inspired many people, from writers to riders. In this article, we will explore some of the most beautiful horse quotes.

Horse quotes are phrases or expressions that reflect on a horse. These quotes highlight the beauty, strength, and spirit of horses. They show the bond between horses and humans. They also show how to ride and care for horses. Horse quotes can inspire, celebrate, and honor the uniqueness of horses.

Without further ado, let's take a look at these insightful horse quotes and discover how these animals hold a special place in our hearts.

Horse Quotes from Famous Figure

  • “Horses change lives. They give out young people confidence and self-esteem. They provide peace and tranquility to troubled souls, they give us hope.” — Toni Robinson

  • “A horse loves freedom, and the weariest old work horse will roll on the ground or break into a lumbering gallop when he is turned loose into the open.” — Gerald Rafferty

  • "No hour of life is wasted that is spent in the saddle." — Winston Churchill

  • “Horses make a landscape look beautiful.” — Alice Walker

  • "A man on a horse is spiritually, as well as physically, bigger than a man on foot." — John Steinbeck

  • "I can make a general in five minutes but a good horse is hard to replace."— Abraham Lincoln

  • "Horse sense is the thing a horse has which keeps it from betting on people." — W.C. Fields

  • ​​"I can make a General in five minutes, but a good horse is hard to replace." — Abraham Lincoln

  • "No philosophers so thoroughly comprehend us as dogs and horses." — Herman Melville

  • "There's something about the outside of a horse that is good for the inside of a man." — Winston Churchill

Horse Quotes from Literature

  • "There is much we can learn from a friend who happens to be a horse." ― Aleksandra Layland, "Bind Not the Heart: A Windflower Saga Novella"

  • "Horses were never wrong. They always did what they did for a reason, and it was up to you to figure it out." ― Jeannette Walls, Half Broke Horses

  • "Most horses don't walk backward voluntarily, because what they can't see doesn't exist." — Terry Pratchett, Soul Music

  • "I help horses with people problems." - Tom Booker, The Horse Whisperer

  • "You see I've been through the desert on a horse with no name, it felt good to be out of the rain." - America, A Horse With No Name

  • "'I don't like people,' said Velvet. '... I only like horses.'" — Enid Bagnold, National Velvet
  •  "I'm back in the saddle again, out where a friend is a friend." - Gene Autry, Back In The Saddle Again

  • "My good horse, you've lost nothing but your self-respect." - C.S. Lewis, The Horse and His Boy

  • "He had seen the world through little boys' and horses' eyes." - John Steinbeck, The Red Pony

  • "Horses are such agreeable friends—they ask no questions, they pass no criticisms." - Margaret Mitchell, Gone with the Wind

Horse Quotes to Inspire You

  • "From horses, we may learn not only about the horse itself but also about animals in general, indeed about ourselves and about life as a whole." ― George Gaylord Simpson

  • "A horse is the projection of peoples' dreams about themselves – strong, powerful, beautiful – and it has the capability of giving us escape from our mundane existence." – Pam Brown

  • "Every different horse has a different personality, like a human." – Nikola Jokic

  • "A horse is a thing of beauty… none will tire of looking at him as long as he displays himself in his splendor." – Xenophon
  • "You never know how a horse will pull until you hook him to a heavy load." – Bear Bryant

  • "No horse gets anywhere until he is harnessed. No stream or gas drives anything until it is confined. No Niagara is ever turned into light and power until it is tunneled. No life ever grows great until it is focused, dedicated, disciplined." – Harry Emerson Fosdick

  • "Remember that a painting – before it is a battle horse, a nude model, or some anecdote – is essentially a flat surface covered with colours assembled in a certain order." – Maurice Denis

  • "The horse is an archetypal symbol which will always find ways to stir up deep and moving ancestral memories in every human being." —Paul Mellon

  • "Of all animals kept for the recreation of mankind, the horse is alone capable of exciting a passion that shall be absolutely hopeless." —Bret Harte

  • "Horses lend us the wings we lack." —Anonymous

Not Eskimo! 8 Fascinating Facts of Inuit People

Not Eskimo! 8 Fascinating Facts of Inuit People

Dive into the rich culture of the Inuit people with these fascinating facts that unveil their unique way of life, traditions, and resilience. 

Swipe to Learn More!

Not Asian

Although they have oriental look, Inuit are not Asian at all. They are descended from the Thule people, who themselves originated in Siberia and have lived in the Arctic region for more than a thousand years!

Not Eskimo

It's a common mistake, but it's important to know that the Inuit people are not Eskimo. The term "Eskimo" is outdated and not preferred. Inuit is the correct name for these strong and unique Arctic people.

Amazing Kayakers

Inuit hunters are great at using kayaks, small boats, to hunt in icy waters. They're skilled at navigating and catching marine animals.

Special Singing

Inuit women have a cool singing tradition called 'katajjaq' or throat singing. It's like a friendly singing competition where they make different sounds at the same time.

Stories Matter

Inuit people share their history and lessons through stories. They pass down their knowledge and values by talking and telling tales.

Beautiful Art

Inuit art is diverse and beautiful. They create carvings, prints, and sculptures that show their connection to nature and animals.

Snow Homes

Igloos, made from snow, are temporary houses Inuit use in winter. These clever structures keep them warm and cozy in the cold.

Sled Dogs

Inuit have been using sled dogs for a very long time. These loyal dogs help with transportation and hunting, and they are important members of the Inuit community.

Who is Suchanna Seth? CEO of AI Start-Up That Allegedly Kills Her 4-Year-Old Son

Suchana Seth was on the 100 Brilliant Women in AI Ethics List in 2021.

Who is Suchanna Seth? CEO of AI Start-Up That Allegedly Kills Her 4-Year-Old Son

Suchana Seth is a 39-year-old CEO of an AI startup in Bengaluru, India.

She was arrested on Monday evening for allegedly killing his four-year-old son at a service apartment in Goa.

She was arrested in Chitradurga district of Karnataka.

At that time, she tried to escape by taxi with her son's body in a bag.

The motive for the murder is not yet fully known. 

However, early investigations pointed to an "relationship" with Suchana's husband as a factor.

Who is Suchana Seth?

According to her LinkedIn profile, Suchana is an AI ethicist and data scientist with over 12 years of experience.

She mentors data science teams and develops machine learning solutions at startups.

She founded The Mindful AI Lab, a technical consultancy offering AI ethics consulting services, AI system audits, and responsible AI roadmaps for organizations.

Her LinkedIn profile also states that Seth was a researcher at the Raman Research Institute from 2008-2011, where she reportedly met her husband.

However, sources from the institute said that she left in 2010. Seth is also a director at Saatvik Machine Intelligence Technologies Private Limited.

It is a company registered in September 2020 and is currently active.

Who is her husband?

Her husband, Venkataraman PR, is a data scientist with a Ph.D. in Physics.

He is an executive at a financial services company, as well.

On August 8, 2022, Seth filed a domestic violence case against her husband during the divorce proceedings.

They are also involved in a fight for custody of their son.

Suchana was on the 100 Brilliant Women in AI Ethics List in 2021. According to her LinkedIn profile, she has been a member (2017-18) and affiliate (2018-19) of the Berkman Klein Center at Harvard University.

According to North Goa Superintendent of Police, Nidhin Valsan said about the CCTV footage of the hotel.

They found that Suchana Seth had entered the hotel with a child, but checked out alone.

“The child was found with a head injury, the throat was also slashed. If the heinous act had been done in the room, there would have been a lot more blood in the room,” the police official told News18.
